titleInfo.title: Laundry Facilities at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society

physicalDescription.extent: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
physicalDescription.note: Handwritten on envelope: ''#453 JCRS Buildings, #453 JCRS Physical Plant''. On back of photograph: ''#453 JCRS''. Typed notes that were attached to the photograph: ''Shown above are some of the eight pressers in constant daily use in the laundry at the Denver Sanatorium of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society. Four are operated by steam and four by compressed air. The laundry is virtually the only department of the Sanatorium where patients or former patients are not employed, as the duties are too strenuous. 1-2-41''

mods.abstract: Interior of the laundry facilities on the campus of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). Shown are some of the eight pressers in constant daily use. Four are operated by steam and four by compressed air. The laundry was the only department of the sanatorium where patients or former patients were not employed, as the duties were too strenuous. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
mods.note: Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.
